title: Publications
text: Babnigg, György, and Carol S Giometti. 2006. “A database of unique protein sequence identifiers for proteome studies.” Proteomics 6 (16): 4514–22. https://doi.org/10.1002/pmic.200600032.

title: SEGUID v2: Checksums for Linear, Circular, Single- and Double-Stranded Biological Sequences
text:
WARNING: This is work under construction! Please do not use this in production until we’ve offically released SEGUID v2.
The SEquence Globally Unique IDentifier (SEGUID) checksum (Babnigg and Giometti 2006) was introduced to provide a stable, unifying key for the same sequence in different databases facilitating linking protein sequences across databases. SEGUID v2 (2024) extends the original SEGUID method to support also double-stranded sequences (e.g. DNA) and circular sequences (e.g. proteins and double-stranded DNA).

title: SEGUID v2: Checksums for Linear, Circular, Single- and Double-Stranded Biological Sequences
text:
Examples

PythonRCLI (Python)CLI (R)


>>> from seguid import *

>>> ldseguid("ATATGCC", "GGCATAT")
'ldseguid=UnHLvKWgR_kAuUDz5D5zDYcYA7g'

>>> cdseguid("TATGCCA", "TGGCATA")
'cdseguid=UnHLvKWgR_kAuUDz5D5zDYcYA7g'


> library(seguid)

> ldseguid("ATATGCC", "GGCATAT")
[1] "ldseguid=UnHLvKWgR_kAuUDz5D5zDYcYA7g"

> cdseguid("TATGCCA", "TGGCATA")
[1] "cdseguid=UnHLvKWgR_kAuUDz5D5zDYcYA7g"


$ python -m seguid --type=ldseguid <<< $'ATATGCC\nTATACGG'
ldseguid=UnHLvKWgR_kAuUDz5D5zDYcYA7g

$ python -m seguid --type=cdseguid <<< $'TATGCCA\nATACGGT'
cdseguid=UnHLvKWgR_kAuUDz5D5zDYcYA7g


$ Rscript -e seguid::seguid --type=ldseguid <<< $'ATATGCC\nTATACGG'
ldseguid=UnHLvKWgR_kAuUDz5D5zDYcYA7g

$ Rscript -e seguid::seguid --type=cdseguid <<< $'TATGCCA\nATACGGT'
cdseguid=UnHLvKWgR_kAuUDz5D5zDYcYA7g

title: SEGUID v2: Checksums for Linear, Circular, Single- and Double-Stranded Biological Sequences
text:
Availability
Implementations of above SEGUID methods are currently available for Python and R;

sgeuid (Python package)
sgeuid (R package)

title: Quality
text: It is critical that any SEGUID checksums generated are correct. We have composed a set of unit tests that validate the correctness of any implementation. All SEGUID v2 implementations have to pass these tests before being released. We rely on continuous integration (CI) tests on GitHub Actions to check every modification to the different codebases. Any future implementation in another programming language has to undergo the same strict testing.
